metadata.title: 9-Hole  Peg Test •As quickly as possible, the subject must take the pegs from the container one at a time and place them into the holes on the board. He or she must then remove the pegs from the holes one by one and place them back into the container •The board should be placed at the patient's midline, with the container holding the pegs closer to the hand being tested •Standardized instructions should be provided while the activity is demonstrated –The patient should be instructed to “pick up the pegs one at a time and put them into the holes in any order until the holes are all filled. Then remove the pegs one at a time and put them into the container” •Only the hand being evaluated should be used during the test –The dominant hand should be tested first. In hemiplegic patients, the unaffected side should be tested first •One practice trial (per hand) should be provided prior to timing the test •A stopwatch should be used to time the subject, and time should be recorded in seconds(7,8) –The stopwatch is started when the patient touches the first peg –The stopwatch is stopped when the patient places the last peg in the container •Verbal encouragement should be provided (e.g., examiner should say “faster” while patient is performing the test, or “out again, fast” when the patient puts the last peg into the board)(7)
description: The 9-Hole  Peg Test (9-HPT)  was originally designed for patients who had a stroke, but it can be used with a wide range of populations, including patients with various neurological impairments (e.g., Parkinson’s disease, multiple sclerosis)
It may also be useful for assessment of patients who have sustained orthopedic injuries (e.g., digit amputation)(18)
indications: Screening for fine motor problems in children and adults(2,15)

ICD-10 codes.C69-C72: Neoplasms of eye, brain and other parts of central nervous system
ICD-10 codes.M00-M99: Diseases of the musculoskeletal system and connective tissue (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

CPT codes.97161: 97162, or 97163 Initial Physical Therapy Evaluation (code used based on the complexity of the evaluation)
CPT codes.97165: 97166, or 97167 Initial Occupational Therapy Evaluation (code used based on the complexity of the evaluation)
CPT codes.97750: Physical Performance Test or Measurement, with written report

reimbursement: Reimbursement will depend on insurance contract coverage. No specific special agencies are applicable for this assessment, and no specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
psychometric properties: Reliability –Excellent intra-rater  reliability in healthy young adults(7,8) –Excellent interrater reliability in healthy young adults(7,8) –Excellent interrater reliability in patients with chronic stroke in a study in the United Kingdom(9) –Adequate test-retest  reliability in a sample of patients tested tested on different days in a sample of patients and good interrater reliability in a study of patients with mild to moderate PD(17) -Score variance may be associated with fluctuations. Improved performance and decreased measurement error are seen with use of a mean value of 3 trials of the test versus a single trial score –High test-rest  reliability when given to patients with chronic stroke, with an ICC = 0.83–0.99(14)

Validity –Construct validity in healthy volunteers -Correlates with hand function as measured by the Applied Dexterity section of the Arthritis Hand Function Test(10) –Construct validity in children -A significant difference in 9-HPT  test scores between regular and special education students, in a study conducted in the United States, provides evidence of construct validity in children(4) –Concurrent validity in children -A moderate correlation was found with the Purdue Pegboard Test(4) -A negative correlation found between time to complete the 9-HPT  and age, when tested in 5–10-year-olds, indicates that there is adequate concurrent validity. There is a negative correlation between age and fine motor dexterity in children(4) -Older children were faster than younger ones, as would be expected based on developmental research

Internal consistency –Although subjects perform more efficiently using their dominant hands, the difference between hands was observed only during the peg-placement  phase in an assessment of psychometrics during the 9-HPT  in a study conducted in Japan. Differences were negligible during the peg-removal phase(11) -The discrepancy between peg-placement  and peg-removal efficiency suggests that the phases should be discriminated(11)

Ceiling/floor effects –In patients with MS, 9-HPT  may not be sensitive enough to detect deficits in patients with mild disability(12) –Although it is a timed test, a ceiling effect may be seen in patients with severe disability(12)
potential complications adverse effects: Cannot be used with patients with severely impaired hand function
Cannot be used with patients with significant intellectual impairment
Motivation, temperature, and time of day may be influencing factors
test preparation materials required: Equipment required –Board (wood or plastic): with 9 holes (10 mm diameter, 15 mm depth) placed 32 mm(7) or 50 mm apart(9) –A container for the pegs: a square box (100 x 100 x 10 mm) apart from the board or a shallow round dish at the end of the board(8) –Ninepegs (7 mm diameter, 32 mm length)(7) –A stopwatch
Patient is seated at a table
test procedure: As quickly as possible, the subject must take the pegs from the container one at a time and place them into the holes on the board. He or she must then remove the pegs from the holes one by one and place them back into the container
The board should be placed at the patient's midline, with the container holding the pegs closer to the hand being tested

Standardized instructions should be provided while the activity is demonstrated –The patient should be instructed to “pick up the pegs one at a time and put them into the holes in any order until the holes are all filled. Then remove the pegs one at a time and put them into the container”
Only the hand being evaluated should be used during the test –The dominant hand should be tested first. In hemiplegic patients, the unaffected side should be tested first
One practice trial (per hand) should be provided prior to timing the test

A stopwatch should be used to time the subject, and time should be recorded in seconds(7,8) –The stopwatch is started when the patient touches the first peg –The stopwatch is stopped when the patient places the last peg in the container
Verbal encouragement should be provided (e.g., examiner should say “faster” while patient is performing the test, or “out again, fast” when the patient puts the last peg into the board)(7)
test scoring interpretation: Scores are based on the time taken to complete the test activity, in seconds

Alternative scoring is sometimes used for patients who cannot complete the task in 50 or 100 seconds. The number of pegs placed in 50 or 100 seconds can be recorded, and the results expressed as the number of pegs placed per second(1)

Reported norms indicate that, on average, healthy male adults complete the 9-HPT  in 19.0 seconds with the right hand and in 20.6 seconds with the left hand. Healthy female adults complete it in 17.9 seconds with the right hand and in 19.6 seconds with the left hand(7)

Authors of a study designed to determine reference values for several functional outcome measures for persons ages 3 to 101 determined the following for the 9-HPT:  (2) –Age 3–9 years: male 9.2 seconds; female 12.6 seconds –Age 10–19:  male 2.4 seconds; female 2.7 seconds –Age 20–59:  male 2.6 seconds; female 2.2 seconds –Age 60 +: male 5.5 seconds; female 3.7 seconds

The 9-HPT  is a component of the National Institutes of Health (NIH) Toolbox for the Assessment of Neurological and Behavioral Function, which provides a set of assessment tools that can be used across the lifespan (3–85  years)(13) –Norms of the 9-HPT  that can be used to determine the presence of impairments in dexterity across this age span have been established as part of the NIH Toolbox Norming Project(13) –A sample of 4,319 subjects contributed data –Dexterity improved with age through childhood and then declined as individuals aged –The youngest age group (children aged 3–5 years) showed the longest completion time with the largest variation. The 16–39  year age group showed the shortest completion times –Females performed slightly better than males across all age groups –Dominant hands were more dexterous than nondominant hands, but only slightly –There were no differences based on handedness or race
Results of the NIH Toolbox Norming Project concur with norms for children aged 4 years through 19 years previously established(4) to assist in identifying children with dexterity deficits

Adult norms for a commercially available 9-HPT  were not statistically different from previously published adult norms(8)  –For each age group, t-test  results indicated no significant differences in the average scores between the study of the commercially available 9-HPT  and the previously reported study

The 9-HPT  is a component of the Multiple Sclerosis Functional Composite (MSFC)(3) –For use in the MSFC, the 9-HPT  is scored using an average of 4 trials. Scores from two trials for each hand are averaged and then converted to the reciprocals of the mean times for each hand; the two reciprocals are then averaged. This score can be used individually or as part of the MSFC score(3)
